questions.text: Which of the following cereals contains the best quality protein
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Rice is often considered to have the best quality protein among cereals.

  • While rice protein is also deficient in lysine, it has a higher proportion of other essential amino acids, making it relatively more balanced in terms of amino acid composition.
  • Additionally, certain varieties of rice, such as brown rice, may have slightly higher protein content and nutritional quality compared to polished white rice.

Wheat (Option A): While wheat is a staple cereal crop consumed worldwide, it is not considered to have the highest quality protein. Wheat protein is deficient in the essential amino acid lysine, which reduces its protein quality compared to other cereals.

Maize (Corn) (Option B): Maize is another widely consumed cereal, but its protein quality is relatively lower compared to some other cereals. Like wheat, maize protein is deficient in lysine, which affects its overall protein quality.

Jowar (Sorghum) (Option D): Jowar is a drought-tolerant cereal crop commonly grown in dry regions. While jowar is nutritionally rich and provides several essential nutrients, including protein, its protein quality is not typically considered as high as that of rice. Like other cereals mentioned, jowar protein is deficient in lysine.

questions.text: The protein requirement of an adult is
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The protein requirement of an adult is 0.83 g/kg of egg protein and 1 g/kg of mixed vegetable protein.

  • The protein requirement is generally expressed in terms of grams of protein per kilogram of body weight.
  • For egg protein, the requirement is slightly lower, around 0.83 grams per kilogram of body weight.
  • This is because egg protein is considered to be of high quality and has a more balanced amino acid profile.
  • For mixed vegetable protein, which typically contains plant-based sources of protein, the requirement is slightly higher, around 1 gram per kilogram of body weight, due to the lower digestibility and amino acid profile of plant proteins compared to animal proteins.

questions.text: Which one of the following is the best indicator of protein quality for recommending the dietary protein requirement?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Digestible Indispensable Amino Acid Score (DIASS) is a comprehensive measure of the protein quality that considers both the amino acid composition and digestibility of the protein.

  • It evaluates the content of indispensable amino acids (those that the body cannot synthesize) and their digestibility.
  • DIASS provides a more accurate assessment of protein quality and is considered the best indicator for recommending dietary protein requirements.

Protein-efficiency ratio (PER) (Option A): PER is a measure of the weight gained by a test subject per gram of protein consumed. While PER is a useful indicator of protein quality, it does not consider the amino acid composition of the protein, which is essential for determining its nutritional value.

Biological value (BV) (Option B): BV measures the proportion of absorbed protein that is retained and used by the body for protein synthesis. While BV provides information about protein utilization, it does not consider the digestibility of the protein or the amino acid composition.

Digestibility coefficient (Option C): The digestibility coefficient measures the proportion of ingested protein that is absorbed and utilized by the body. While digestibility is important for determining protein quality, it does not provide information about the amino acid composition or essential amino acid content of the protein.

questions.text: What is the protein requirement in a neonate?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The protein requirement of a neonate is between 2.2 to 3.0 grams per body weight.

  • Neonates have high protein requirements due to their rapid growth and development during the early stages of life.
  • Breast milk, which is the recommended source of nutrition for neonates, naturally provides the appropriate amount of protein to support their growth and development.
  • The protein content of breast milk varies depending on factors such as maternal nutrition and stage of lactation.
  • On average, breast milk contains approximately 1.2 to 1.5 grams of protein per 100 milliliters.
  • Given the high rate of growth and development in neonates, their protein requirements are typically estimated to be around 2.2 to 3.0 grams per kilogram of body weight per day.
  • A more appropriate estimate would be around 2.2 to 3.0 grams of protein per kilogram of body weight per day.

questions.text: The highest protein content is in
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Soya bean is known for its exceptionally high protein content (40%).

  • The protein quality in soybeans is relatively high, although methionine is the limiting amino acid (present in lower amounts).
  • Nutritionally rich pulse, soybean is one of the most protein-dense legumes.
  • Composition:
    • Protein: ~40%
    • Fat: ~20%
    • Minerals: ~4%
  • Soya bean is commonly used in various forms, including tofu, tempeh, soya milk, and soya protein isolate.
  • Its high protein content and versatility make it a popular choice among vegetarians, vegans, and individuals looking to increase their protein intake.

Red gram (Pigeon pea) (Option A): While red gram (pigeon pea) is a good source of protein, it typically contains lower protein content compared to soya bean. Red gram is commonly consumed in various cuisines and is valued for its protein content, but it is not as high in protein as the soya bean.

Black gram (Urad dal) (Option B): Black gram, also known as urad dal, is another legume rich in protein. It is commonly used in Indian cuisine to make dishes like dal makhani and idlis. However, its protein content is generally lower than that of the soya bean.

Bengal gram (Chickpea) (Option C): Bengal gram, also known as chickpea or garbanzo bean, is a nutritious legume that contains a moderate amount of protein. It is widely used in various cuisines around the world, including Indian, Middle Eastern, and Mediterranean cuisines. While Bengal gram is a good source of protein, it typically has lower protein content compared to the soya bean.

questions.text: The daily requirement of Vitamin A for an adult man is
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The recommended dietary allowance (RDA) for vitamin A for adult men is 1000 micrograms (mcg) per day.

Sources of Vitamin A

  • Animal Foods (Preformed Vitamin A - Retinol)
    • Rich sources include:
      • Liver (especially fish liver oils- richest natural source)
      • Eggs
      • Butter
      • Cheese
      • Whole milk
      • Fish
      • Meat
    • Fish liver oils are mainly used as nutritional supplements, not regular food.
  • Plant Foods (Provitamin A - Carotenes)
    • Contains beta-carotene, the most important carotenoid with the highest vitamin A activity.
    • Common sources:
      • Green leafy vegetables (e.g., spinach, amaranth)
        • The darker the leaves, the higher the carotene content.
      • Yellow and orange fruits and vegetables (e.g., papaya, mango, pumpkin)
      • Roots (e.g., carrots)
    • Carotenes are converted to vitamin A in the small intestine.
      • This conversion is inefficient in malnourished children and those with diarrhoea.
  • Fortified Foods
    • Important additional sources in the diet include:
      • Vanaspati
      • Margarine
      • Fortified milk

Storage and Metabolism of Vitamin A:

  • Vitamin A is stored in the liver, mostly in the form of retinol palmitate.
  • A well-nourished individual has enough liver reserves to meet vitamin A needs for 6 to 9 months.
  • Free retinol is highly active but toxic.
    • It is transported in the bloodstream bound to retinol-binding protein (RBP).
    • RBP is produced by the liver.
    • In cases of severe protein deficiency, RBP production decreases, leading to impaired transport of vitamin A.

questions.text: Which vitamin is related to the daily requirement for proteins?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Pyridoxine (vitamin B6) is directly related to the daily requirement for proteins because it is involved in amino acid metabolism.

  • Pyridoxine helps in the synthesis of non-essential amino acids and the conversion of one amino acid to another.
  • Therefore, vitamin B6 plays a crucial role in determining the daily requirement for proteins, as it is essential for the utilization of dietary proteins and the synthesis of new proteins within the body.

B1 (Thiamine) (Option A): Thiamine (vitamin B1) is primarily involved in carbohydrate metabolism and the production of energy from carbohydrates. It is not directly related to the daily requirement for proteins.

B2 (Riboflavin) (Option B): Riboflavin (vitamin B2) is involved in energy metabolism, particularly the metabolism of fats and carbohydrates. While it plays a role in the utilization of amino acids, it is not directly related to determining the daily requirement for proteins.

B3 (Niacin) (Option C): Niacin (vitamin B3) is also involved in energy metabolism and plays a role in the metabolism of fats, carbohydrates, and proteins. However, its primary function is not specifically related to determining the daily requirement for proteins.

questions.solution:
Explanation:

Kishori Shakthi Yojana (KSY) is a government scheme aimed at empowering adolescent girls, particularly those from marginalized communities, by providing them with various services and opportunities for holistic development.

Schemes for Adolescent Girls

1. Kishori Shakti Yojana (KSY)

  • Implemented using the infrastructure of the Integrated Child Development Services (ICDS).
  • Targets adolescent girls aged 11 to 18 years.
  • Aims to improve:
    • Self-development
    • Nutritional and health status
    • Literacy and numerical skills
    • Vocational training and life skills

2. Nutrition Programme for Adolescent Girls (NPAG)

  • Launched as a pilot project in 2009-10.
  • Implemented in 51 identified districts from major states.
  • Targets undernourished adolescent girls aged 11 to 19 years.
  • Eligibility:
    • Girls aged 11-15 years with body weight < 30 kg
    • Girls aged 15-19 years with body weight < 35 kg
  • Provides 6 kg of free food grains per month to each beneficiary.
  • Implemented through the ICDS administrative structure at the state, district, block, and Anganwadi Centre levels.

Empowerment of females under maternity benefit scheme (Option A): This option refers to schemes focused on providing maternity benefits and support to pregnant and lactating mothers, typically through financial assistance or maternity healthcare services. KSY, however, is specifically targeted at adolescent girls and focuses on their empowerment through education, nutrition, health, and life skills training.

Free and compulsory education for girl child (Option C): This option refers to initiatives aimed at promoting education for girls and ensuring their access to free and compulsory schooling. While education is an essential component of empowerment, KSY focuses on a broader range of services beyond education, including nutrition, health, and life skills training.

Child care home scheme (Option D): This option refers to schemes or programs focused on providing residential care and support to orphaned, abandoned, or destitute children who are unable to live with their families. KSY, however, is targeted specifically at adolescent girls and aims to empower them through various services and opportunities for personal and social development.

questions.text: What is the dosage of vitamin A prophylaxis for a 1-year-old child?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Vitamin A prophylaxis dose for children of 1-6 years is 2,00,000 IU.

Prevention of Vitamin A Deficiency

1. Long-Term Preventive Measures

  • Focus on improving dietary intake to ensure regular consumption of vitamin A-rich foods.
  • Target underlying health issues that increase vitamin A requirements or losses, such as:
    • Protein-energy malnutrition (PEM)
    • Respiratory infections
    • Diarrhoea
    • Measles
  • Require community involvement and nutrition education to promote sustainable change.

2. Short-Term Strategy (Supplementation)

  • Developed by the National Institute of Nutrition (NIN), Hyderabad, as a community-level intervention.
  • Based on the fact that vitamin A is stored in the liver and released gradually over time (lasting 6-9 months).
  • Involves giving high-dose vitamin A supplementation to young children at regular intervals:
    • 200,000 IU of retinol palmitate in oil, given orally every 6 months to children aged 1 to 6 years.
    • 100,000 IU for infants aged 6 months to 1 year. (Option B)
  • This approach acts like a protective shield against xerophthalmia, offering sustained protection.
  • Clinical evidence supports the effectiveness of this biannual dosing schedule in reducing signs of deficiency.

questions.text: What is the RDA for iodine during pregnancy in mcg?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The RDA for iodine during pregnancy is 250 mcg.

Iodine Requirement

  • The recommended daily intake of iodine for a healthy adult is approximately 150 micrograms.
  • During pregnancy, the requirement increases to 250 micrograms per day, as per WHO guidelines.
  • These needs are generally met through a balanced diet and iodine-rich water sources.
  • However, in areas where iodine levels in soil, water, and food are low, dietary intake may be insufficient, increasing the risk of iodine deficiency disorders.

questions.text: The amount of protein that is available to the body for its various growth and maintenance functions, expressed as a percentage of the total protein ingested in the diet, is
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Net protein utilization (NPU) refers to the amount of dietary protein that is actually utilized by the body for various physiological functions, expressed as a percentage of the total protein ingested in the diet.

Net Protein Utilization (NPU)

  • NPU is a measure used to assess the quality of dietary protein.
  • It considers both:
    • How well the protein is digested (digestibility coefficient)
    • How efficiently the absorbed amino acids are used by the body (biological value)

  • This method provides a more comprehensive evaluation of protein quality than amino acid score alone.
  • It is a biological method that requires specialized lab facilities to measure nitrogen intake and retention.
  • For calculations:
    • 1 gram of nitrogen is assumed to be equivalent to 25 grams of protein.
  • The higher the NPU, the less protein is needed in the diet to meet nutritional needs.
    • If NPU is low, the protein requirement increases.
  • NPU of Indian diets typically ranges from 50 to 80, depending on the type and source of protein consumed.

Biological value (Option A): Biological value (BV) is a measure of the proportion of absorbed protein from a food that becomes incorporated into the proteins of the body, typically expressed as a percentage. BV does not directly account for the digestibility of dietary protein, so it does not fully represent the amount of protein available for the body's use.

Digestibility coefficient (Option B): Digestibility coefficient represents the proportion of ingested protein that is digested and absorbed by the body, expressed as a percentage. While the digestibility coefficient is an important factor in determining the availability of dietary protein, it does not account for the body's ability to utilize the absorbed amino acids for protein synthesis and other metabolic processes.

Total body nitrogen (Option D): Total body nitrogen refers to the sum of nitrogen-containing compounds in the body, primarily proteins. While nitrogen balance and measurements of total body nitrogen can provide information about protein status in the body, they do not specifically quantify the efficiency of protein utilization from the diet.

questions.text: Daily energy requirement, when measured in terms of kcal per kg of body weight, is highest for
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Infants have the highest daily energy requirement per kilogram of body weight compared to other age groups.

  • This is because infants have rapid growth and development, high metabolic rates, and significant energy demands to support various physiological processes, including growth, development, and thermoregulation.

Adult man doing hard work (Option A): While adults engaged in strenuous physical activity may have increased energy requirements compared to sedentary individuals, their energy needs per kilogram of body weight are typically lower than those of infants. However, their absolute energy requirements may be higher due to increased physical activity levels.

Boy aged 16-17 years (Option B): Adolescents, particularly boys during the peak of growth and development, also have increased energy requirements compared to adults. However, their energy needs per kilogram of body weight are generally lower than those of infants due to slower growth rates and maturation of metabolic processes.

Children 1-9 years (Option D): Energy requirements for children aged 1-9 years vary depending on factors such as age, sex, growth rate, and physical activity level. While children in this age group may have relatively high energy needs compared to adults, their energy requirements per kilogram of body weight are typically lower than those of infants due to slower growth rates and maturation of metabolic processes.

questions.text: The protein efficacy ratio is defined as
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The protein efficiency ratio (PER) is a measure used to evaluate the quality of a protein by assessing its ability to support growth in animals. It is determined by measuring the gain in weight of young animals per unit weight of protein consumed in the diet over a specific period of time.

The product of the digestibility coefficient and the biological value (Option B): This option is not correct because the protein efficiency ratio is not calculated as the product of the digestibility coefficient and the biological value. While these parameters are important in assessing protein quality, they are not directly used in determining the protein efficiency ratio.

The percentage of protein absorbed into the blood (Option C): This option describes protein absorption efficiency, which is different from the protein efficiency ratio. The protein efficiency ratio focuses on the growth-promoting effects of dietary protein in animals rather than its absorption into the blood.

The percentage of nitrogen absorbed from the protein absorbed from the diet (Option D): This option describes nitrogen balance, which is another method used to assess protein utilization in the body, but is different from the protein efficiency ratio. Nitrogen balance compares the amount of nitrogen ingested with the amount excreted and retained in the body, whereas the protein efficiency ratio specifically measures growth outcomes in animals fed with different protein sources.

questions.text: Food standards in India have to achieve a minimum level of quality under
questions.solution:
Explanation:

PFA stands for the Prevention of Food Adulteration Act, which was an old legislation in India governing food safety and standards.

Prevention of Food Adulteration (PFA) Act, 1954

  • Enacted by the Indian Parliament in 1954 to ensure the supply of pure and safe food to consumers.
  • Aimed to protect public health and curb fraudulent and misleading food practices.
  • The Act was amended in 1964, 1976, and 1986 to strengthen its provisions.

Penalties Under the PFA Act:

  • Minimum punishment for confirmed adulteration:
    • 6 months imprisonment
    • Minimum fine of 1,000
  • In cases where adulteration leads to grievous harm or death:
    • Punishment may extend to life imprisonment
    • Fine not less than 5,000

Powers and Implementation:

  • The 1986 amendment empowered consumers and voluntary organizations to collect food samples.
  • Food safety rules are framed and periodically updated by the Central Committee for Food Standards, an expert body under the Central Government.
  • Foods that do not meet prescribed standards are considered adulterated.

Enforcement and Infrastructure:

  • Though it's a Central Act, implementation is done by state governments and local bodies.
  • The Central Government ensures coordination, monitoring, and oversight.
  • A network of food testing laboratories exists, including four regional Central Food Laboratories (in Kolkata, Mysore, Ghaziabad, and Pune) whose decisions are considered final.

While all the options listed are related to food standards or quality assurance in some way, the Bureau of Indian Standards (BIS) (Option B) primarily deals with setting standards for industrial and consumer products, including food items, through the formulation of Indian Standards (IS). These standards cover various aspects of product quality, safety, and performance. However, the BIS is not solely focused on food standards; it covers a wide range of products and sectors.

Codex Alimentarius (Option A) is an international food standards body jointly established by the Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO) and the World Health Organization (WHO). It develops international food standards, guidelines, and codes of practice to ensure the safety, quality, and fairness of international food trade. While Codex standards influence food regulations worldwide, they are not specific to India.

Agmark standards (Option C) are related to agricultural products, including grains, pulses, spices, and vegetable oils, in India. The Agmark certification is a quality assurance mark that indicates compliance with the specified standards for agricultural commodities. However, it does not cover all food products, and its scope is limited to certain agricultural items.

Explanation:

The Codex Alimentarius Commission, established by the Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO) and the World Health Organization (WHO), develops international food standards, guidelines, and codes of practice.

  • These standards aim to protect consumer health and ensure fair practices in the food trade.
  • Codex standards cover a wide range of food products, additives, contaminants, and hygiene practices, providing globally recognized benchmarks for food safety and quality.

BIS standards (Option A): The Bureau of Indian Standards (BIS) is responsible for formulating and certifying Indian Standards (IS) across various sectors, including food. While BIS standards ensure the quality, safety, and performance of products in India, they are specific to the country's regulatory framework and are not international food standards.

Agmark standards (Option C): The Agmark certification is a quality assurance mark issued by the Directorate of Marketing and Inspection (DMI), Ministry of Agriculture, Government of India. It applies to agricultural products such as grains, pulses, spices, and vegetable oils. Agmark standards ensure that these products meet specific quality parameters and are graded accordingly. However, Agmark standards are limited to agricultural commodities in India and do not encompass international food standards.

PFA standards (Option D): The Prevention of Food Adulteration (PFA) Act was an Indian legislation aimed at preventing food adulteration and ensuring food safety and quality within the country. However, the PFA Act has been repealed and replaced by the Food Safety and Standards Act (FSSA), which established the Food Safety and Standards Authority of India (FSSAI). Therefore, PFA standards are no longer applicable, and they do not represent international food standards.
